After going through the Running Geth - Creating a Private Blockchain tutorial at the end of chapter 2, shortly after I discovered Geth actually has a dev mode that does essentially the same thing with some nice shortcuts, like starting/stopping mining only when there are transactions in the queue. Is there an advantage/reason to prefer the setup method described in the tutorial versus using dev mode, or was it just to give us some more hands on experience of setting up a single-node network?
Here's the info on dev mode BTW: https://geth.ethereum.org/docs/getting-started/dev-mode

Degenicus 05-Sep-21 05:26 AM
It was easier to just change the commands and not update, here it is in case someone needs it:
geth --allow-insecure-unlock --datadir . --keystore ~/.ethereum/keystore --networkid 4568 --rpc --rpcaddr '0.0.0.0' --rpccorsdomain "*" --rpcport 8502 --rpcapi 'personal,eth,net,web3,txpool,miner' --mine --miner.etherbase=some eth addr
alo42 05-Sep-21 01:25 PM
Here's a scripted version of the Ethereum address generator in the "Generating Ethereum Address" chapter: https://github.com/alo9507/ethereum-hd-wallet-step-by-step Found an answer to my question of how multiple addresses come from a single mnemonic: you change the derivation path to get a new private key per address
GitHub - alo9507/ethereum-hd-wallet-step-by-step
Contribute to alo9507/ethereum-hd-wallet-step-by-step development by creating an account on GitHub.
https://medium.com/myetherwallet/hd-wallets-and-derivation-paths-explained-865a643c7bf2
HD Wallets and Derivation Paths: Explained
When accessing the blockchain with a hardware wallet or mnemonic phrase, you have the ability to interact with a seemingly infinite amount…

I know the format is m / purpose / coin_type / account / change / address_index, so I assume changing the account` number is how you get a new account from the same mnemonic/seed? (edited)

The bip39 library is really just one 181 line JS file and some wordlists. Technically, you could add your own word list: https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bip39/blob/327a17b8df997a19d915a97b463117281ded773b/src/index.js

Regina | UTC+10 | AU 07-Sep-21 01:54 AM
The Ethereum address of 0xdcc703c0e500b653ca82273b7bfad8045d85a470 (PubHashEmptyStr) is derived from a keccak256 hash performed on an empty "" string, instead of an ECDSA public key. This address has had 815.643 ETH transferred to it over 28 transactions spanning roughly 3 years that is irrecoverably lost.

// Add imports here const BIP39 = require("bip39") // Generate a random mnemonic (uses crypto.randomBytes under the hood), defaults to 128-bits of entropy function generateMnemonic(){ return BIP39.generateMnemonic() } const hdkey = require('ethereumjs-wallet/hdkey') const Wallet = require('ethereumjs-wallet') // Add functions here function generateSeed(mnemonic){ return BIP39.mnemonicToSeed(mnemonic) } function derivePubKey(privKey){ const wallet = Wallet.fromPrivateKey(privKey) return wallet.getPublicKey() }
Piji 07-Sep-21 08:24 AM
this is my full code:
// Add imports here const BIP39 = require("bip39"); const hdkey = require('ethereumjs-wallet/hdkey'); const Wallet = require('ethereumjs-wallet'); const keccak256 = require('js-sha3').keccak256; const EthereumTx = require('ethereumjs-tx'); // Add functions here function generateMnemonic(){ return BIP39.generateMnemonic() } var isValid = BIP39.validateMnemonic("horse") // This will return false function generateSeed(mnemonic){ return BIP39.mnemonicToSeed(mnemonic) } function generatePrivKey(mnemonic){ const seed = generateSeed(mnemonic) return hdkey.fromMasterSeed(seed).derivePath(`m/44'/60'/0'/0/0`).getWallet().getPrivateKey() } function derivePubKey(privKey){ const wallet = Wallet.fromPrivateKey(privKey) return wallet.getPublicKey() } function deriveEthAddress(pubKey){ const address = keccak256(pubKey) // keccak256 hash of publicKey // Get the last 20 bytes of the public key return "0x" + address.substring(address.length - 40, address.length) } function getSignerAddress(signedTx){ return "0x" + signedTx.getSenderAddress().toString('hex') } function signTx(privKey, txData){ const tx = new EthereumTx(txData) tx.sign(privKey) return tx }

// Add imports here const BIP39 = require("bip39"); const hdkey = require('ethereumjs-wallet/hdkey'); const Wallet = require('ethereumjs-wallet'); const keccak256 = require('js-sha3').keccak256; const EthereumTx = require('ethereumjs-tx'); // Add functions here function generateMnemonic(){ return BIP39.generateMnemonic() } var isValid = BIP39.validateMnemonic("horse") // This will return false function generateSeed(mnemonic){ return BIP39.mnemonicToSeed(mnemonic) } function generatePrivKey(mnemonic){ const seed = generateSeed(mnemonic) return hdkey.fromMasterSeed(seed).derivePath(`m/44'/60'/0'/0/0`).getWallet().getPrivateKey() } function derivePubKey(privKey){ const wallet = Wallet.fromPrivateKey(privKey) return wallet.getPublicKey() } function deriveEthAddress(pubKey){ const address = keccak256(pubKey) // keccak256 hash of publicKey // Get the last 20 bytes of the public key return "0x" + address.substring(address.length - 40, address.length) } function getSignerAddress(signedTx){ return "0x" + signedTx.getSenderAddress().toString('hex') } function signTx(privKey, txData){ const tx = new EthereumTx(txData) tx.sign(privKey) return tx }

For normal user accounts e.g Externally owned accounts codeHash is just an empty string, whereas if account is a contract account it has the code that gets stored on blockchain. storageRoot is built froma Merkle tree of storage data for account and as far as I think has nothing to do with contract code, in many cases it maybe empty

thedarkjester 09-Sep-21 02:27 PM
What happens is (my understanding) People pay fees for transactions and their balance is reduced. Then, when allocating to the miner, it is just the tips and block rewards added to their balance. Effectively base fees are just not allocated and goes into thin air. Look at: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-1559.md Search for burn (keep going next till you see where balances are adjusred) (edited)
EIPs/eip-1559.md at master · ethereum/EIPs
The Ethereum Improvement Proposal repository. Contribute to ethereum/EIPs development by creating an account on GitHub.
There is no law that it has to go somewhere

I have a question about "Running out of gas topic" based on this paragraph below: If a transaction’s instructions run out of gas mid-execution while a miner is processing it, it’s then “reverted back to its original state”, meaning the transaction has been returned to the sender. Regardless,* the sender must still pay a fee to miners to compensate them for the computational power they spent processing the transaction, even if it was partially completed. *Miners must also add the transaction to the blockchain, even if it wasn’t fully executed. If the sender specified a higher gas limit than was necessary, the miner would refund the difference to the sender. the sender must still pay a fee to miners to compensate them for the computational power they spent processing the transaction, even if it was partially completed. Can someone help me confirm that the sender will actually lose money on this transaction? I feel like this is not the fault of the sender for executing the smart contract and they should be entitled to 100% refund. What does everyone think?

Craig Banach 10-Sep-21 09:20 AM
More transactions per block mean more transactions for a node to check, means each node must be more powerful, means people that can't afford powerful nodes don't run nodes and you have less decentralization.
Craig Banach

dstn 12-Sep-21 01:32 PM
Reading through some of the ethereum developer docs and still not quite grasping the relationship between transactions, blocks and miners. Regarding transactions the docs say: Transactions, which change the state of the EVM, need to be broadcast to the whole network. Any node can broadcast a request for a transaction to be executed on the EVM; after this happens, a miner will execute the transaction and propagate the resulting state change to the rest of the network. Regarding blocks the docs say: We batch transactions into blocks. This means dozens (or hundreds) of transactions are committed, agreed on, and synchronized on all at once. So...are transactions only performed by the winning miner and therefore only the new state is broadcast? Or do all nodes execute all the transactions after a miner mines a block? If only the miner performs the state change how do we know the miner executed them correctly? If all the nodes are executing the transactions to validate them aren't we wasting a ton of energy to have a bunch of computers running the same code when only the new state is valuable? (edited)

dstn

thedarkjester 12-Sep-21 03:08 PM
There are different types of nodes and miner interaction. As an example, I run an archive erigon node but don't mine through it. The node accepts transactions if they look valid and validates the blocks produced by miner nodes and stores the longest chain. Miner nodes/pool nodes will compile blocks (last block hash and some transactions in the mempool), and then search for a nonce to meet the current block difficulty. Erigon does execute each transaction to optimise space as well as validate the state changes (edited)

thedarkjester 12-Sep-21 06:14 PM
Verifying and validating takes little energy (I run it on a raspberry pi that uses about 10w of power of the 15w power supply) The real energy is in the proof of work. I do it to help keep the network up and to validate the miner data
thedarkjester 12-Sep-21 06:24 PM
The compensation for me is that: 1. I can send my transactions through a node I trust 2. Check my transactions through a node I trust 3. I can help propagate transactions to other nodes quicker 4. I can help provide data for other nodes to sync with 5. Helps the network stay up with another node 6. I think it is fun to do

Why are the last 20 bytes of the public key used as the address?
According to this post regarding how to derive the Ethereum address from a public key: Take the last 40 characters / 20 bytes of this public key (Keccak-256). Or, in other words, drop the firs...
2
Vitalik actually provides more context in this thread and answers this well: https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/increasing-address-size-from-20-to-32-bytes/5485/13
Increasing address size from 20 to 32 bytes
How so? Remember that there’s no need for a checksum within the EVM; the checksum is a user-interface-level convenience. So it should be part of the representation format (as the mixed-case-hex thing is), and not part of the raw address format. making such entry more difficult and error prone to enter by making the addresses cases sensitive ...

Can someone tell me what the system and internet requirements for running a light node on testnet are? Panasthetik. 14-Sep-21 09:36 PM
Your spec is totally fine - the geth - - ropsten - - syncmode “light” in the terminal will start Geth and only start to sync the block headers (minimal storage). Also, you’ll notice a few peer nodes at most, and you can stop it any time with CTRL C. You can also create new test accounts with Geth on Ropsten using the light client. To actually mine transactions however, you need to do a real sync for Ropsten, which takes up a lot more space. There will be an alert “mining disabled in light mode” if you try and execute anything that isn’t read-only. Anyone feel free to jump in if I missed anything here!

10delta 14-Sep-21 10:50 PM
I'm wondering why different "actions" on Ethereum have different gas costs associated with them? Why not use a flat rate for all the possible actions? It's my understanding that the gas was implemented to overcome the halting problem, if so, then wouldn't any arbitrary non-trivial fixed gas cost solve this?
Thanks in advance
10delta
I'm wondering why different "actions" on Ethereum have different gas costs associated with them? Why not use a flat rate for all the possible actions? It's my understanding that the gas was implemented to overcome the halting problem, if so, then wouldn't any arbitrary non-trivial fixed gas cost solve this?
keith 14-Sep-21 11:17 PM
I believe the way gas is used in Ethereum is that each computation costs a certain amount of gas to perform. If a certain function in a smart contract logic is simple (for example, a standard transfer function), then it will cost a relatively small amount of gas to call that function. However, a more complex function (for example, an NFT-minting function) might cost more because it is computationally more intensive. Total gas used by the network is the gas price x gas limit. Think of it like this - the gas price is like the price of gasoline that you're paying to put gas in your car. The gas limit is like the gas tank in your car. Each computation eats up a certain amount of the gas limit - this amount never changes for that specific computation. The only thing that changes is the price of the gas people are willing to pay (edited)

In other words, what is the fundamental reason for charging differing gas costs for differing operations? It makes intuitive sense to pay more for more computationally intensive operations, but at a fundamental level is it really necessary to pay more for these operations?

MatricksDeCoder 15-Sep-21 03:42 AM
Dont forget. There is a game theoretic side and economics and incentives side to blockchain. It's all about balancing supply and demand. E.g With fixed fees everyone will send transactions spamming the chain, but fees can rise to indicate adding transcations must come at a premium as blocks are limited, high demand low supply so prices rise and the opposite will be true e.g few transactions, high supply( empty blocks), low demand so prices must be lower to encourage more transactions to fill blocks, miners are in this for profitability.

Is there an explanation as to why the base fee is burnt? Why wouldn't it be distributed to the miners as well? (edited)
nomadicspoon
Is there an explanation as to why the base fee is burnt? Why wouldn't it be distributed to the miners as well? (edited)
Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs 15-Sep-21 12:41 PM
My understanding is that EIP-1559 removes the market aspect from block production by setting a base fee programmatically. As such, it's burned rather than distributed to the miners, who instead get the miner tip and transaction fee. It's fairly controversial and why there were a number of miner pools against EIP-1559
Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs

Amma 16-Sep-21 11:18 AM
Hi @rassenguy Sure Coogan will answer but as I understand it uncle blocks in Ethereum are the same as orphan blocks in Bitcon BUT unlike Bitcoin, in the Ethereum system, miners still receive a block reward for discovering the uncle block. With respect to your question on the relationship to the main chain this might help...... Uncle blocks are created when two blocks are mined and broadcasted at the same time (with the same block number). Since only one of the blocks can enter the primary Ethereum chain, the block that gets validated across more nodes becomes the canonical block, and the other one becomes what is known as an uncle block. Uncle blocks are recorded and accessible from the chain, but they have no impact on the canonical chain and their transactions do not change any state [Elan Halpern]

jccalderonm 16-Sep-21 11:48 AM
Uncle blocks are sort of like a dead end. They include all the chain existing to that point, but are not incorporated on the primary Etherum chain. Nonetheless you can see them in Etherscan.However, they are important into the Ethereum's consensus method called GHOST. "...nodes will get the number of uncles mined for the last seven blocks in each subtree. That number is, in addition to the number of blocks in that subtree, used to calculate the tree’s weight; the heaviest tree is then said to be the 'correct' one."https://medium.com/@philipshen13/ethereum-7e0c8fc47f74
How Ethereum Works
An in-depth-but-not-too-in-depth technical overview of the Ethereum platform

Amma 16-Sep-21 12:11 PM
Hi @SylvainDev_ 🇫🇷 that's how understand it but I am open to correction
Amma
Hi @rassenguy Sure Coogan will answer but as I understand it uncle blocks in Ethereum are the same as orphan blocks in Bitcon BUT unlike Bitcoin, in the Ethereum system, miners still receive a block reward for discovering the uncle block. With respect to your question on the relationship to the main chain this might help...... Uncle blocks are created when two blocks are mined and broadcasted at the same time (with the same block number). Since only one of the blocks can enter the primary Ethereum chain, the block that gets validated across more nodes becomes the canonical block, and the other one becomes what is known as an uncle block. Uncle blocks are recorded and accessible from the chain, but they have no impact on the canonical chain and their transactions do not change any state [Elan Halpern]
rassenguy 16-Sep-21 12:34 PM
thanks for the explanation. i have one more question though, why do the uncle block transactions not change any state ?
rassenguy
thanks for the explanation. i have one more question though, why do the uncle block transactions not change any state ?
Amma 16-Sep-21 01:04 PM
Maybe I confused you you. The uncle block/orphan is not part of the main blockchain - the longest chain. It is essentially forgotten about. No further blocks will be added to it. Only the main blockchain will have blocks added and increase in length/height. (edited)

Kyre 16-Sep-21 03:54 PM
for anyone who has trouble i figured this out. I updated def hash2 to the code below def hash2(first, second): # Reverse inputs before and after hashing due to big-endian / little-endian nonsense # firstreverse = first.decode('hex')[::-1] # secondreverse = second.decode('hex')[::-1] # h = hashlib.sha256(hashlib.sha256(firstreverse+secondreverse).digest()).digest() # return h[::-1].encode('hex') inputParam = str(first) + str(second) inputParam = inputParam.encode() hash = hashlib.sha256(inputParam) return hash.hexdigest() (edited)
1
Kyre
for anyone who has trouble i figured this out. I updated def hash2 to the code below def hash2(first, second): # Reverse inputs before and after hashing due to big-endian / little-endian nonsense # firstreverse = first.decode('hex')[::-1] # secondreverse = second.decode('hex')[::-1] # h = hashlib.sha256(hashlib.sha256(firstreverse+secondreverse).digest()).digest() # return h[::-1].encode('hex') inputParam = str(first) + str(second) inputParam = inputParam.encode() hash = hashlib.sha256(inputParam) return hash.hexdigest() (edited)

Phas0r 17-Sep-21 02:04 PM
Hi, I have a question on EIP 1559 pls. I don't really understand the point of the fee/tip change with respect to users. Before EIP 1559 we had "gas wars" where people would pay through the nose in high gas prices to have an urgent transaction in the next block. Post EIP 1559, don't we still have exactly the same dynamic where people just compete on tips? Since the tips is market driven and variable, doesn't this just get us back to the same position as before, albeit we can break the overall fee into base fee + tip. I must be missing something. Thank you
presumably if you just pay the base fee (no tip) you run the risk of not getting included in the next block when others are paying a tip as well.

thedarkjester 17-Sep-21 02:20 PM
Have you watched https://youtu.be/MGemhK9t44Q
Finematics
Can ETH Become DEFLATIONARY? EIP 1559 Explained
It explains it really well. Yes, you could wait if your gas price is lower than the current running rate and if tips go in, but the level of predictability and wallet interaction is far better for the user.
Phas0r 17-Sep-21 03:21 PM
Thanks. Still struggling a bit with this. Why is the level of predictability higher? I understand that the base fee can only increase by 12.5% per block so this is certainly more predictable, however the total fee paid by the user includes the tip too which is unpredictable, so in a period of very high network activity, you still have a bidding war on tips to get into the next block. The predictability of the overall fee paid by users seems no higher, they are still subject to a very volatile tip. I guess, in extremis, if the tip far outweighs the base fee in dollar terms, we end up in a very similar situation like we had pre EIP 1559.
Phas0r

I understand that the base fee can only increase by 12.5% per block so this is certainly more predictable, however the total fee paid by the user includes the tip too which is unpredictable, so in a period of very high network activity, you still have a bidding war on tips to get into the next block. Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs 17-Sep-21 03:47 PM
The other aspect is the amount of transactions put in blocks. EIP-1559 aims programmatically to keep blocks about 50% empty, IIRC, so there's less crushing demand to get in generally. Now, in moments of spiking prices, there will be an instance where the tip gets too high for almost everyone, but the idea is that those moments last shorter due to the surge pricing model.
1
Phas0r 17-Sep-21 04:10 PM
thanks Coogan, yes that's a good point. The tip doesn't need to be as high in normal conditions since there should be 50% block space remaining absent a huge surge in demand.

If you run npm run watch in your terminal after you have cd'ed into the ethereum-address-generator-js directory, then open another terminal and run npm run reload this will start your server where can interact with it in your browser at http://localhost:8081/. You need to add code to main.js from the lesson to get full functionality.

Panasthetik. 18-Sep-21 11:11 PM
! The IPC file is already created, and it is in a directory specified in the ‘URL” path at the top of the terminal when you first fire up Geth. Depending on your operating system, the correct command in terminal 2 is: geth attach ./<your path>/geth.ipc or for Ubuntu Linux: geth attach ipc://<your path/geth.ipc

SeanM 20-Sep-21 11:00 PM
I'm curious how we know that the substring of address is 20 bytes here? The address is 64 chars long, so address.substring(24, 64) gives us 40 characters. How is that 20 bytes? (I have very little compsci knowledge) (edited)
SeanM
I'm curious how we know that the substring of address is 20 bytes here? The address is 64 chars long, so address.substring(24, 64) gives us 40 characters. How is that 20 bytes? (I have very little compsci knowledge) (edited)
jccalderonm 21-Sep-21 12:09 AM
Each of the 40 characters represent a hexadecimal number. It means you have 40 hexadecimal numbers. One byte represents 8 bits. One hexadecimal number is presented by 4 bits. One byte is represented by a pair of hexadecimal numbers. Then with 20 bytes you represent 40 hexadecimal numbers.

VinnyChase 22-Sep-21 04:19 PM
Why do people run full nodes if you don't get a reward from it?
VinnyChase
Why do people run full nodes if you don't get a reward from it?
thedarkjester 22-Sep-21 04:50 PM
I run an archive node because of a few reasons: 1. To support the eco system and help other nodes propagate transactions quicker on the p2p network 2. I can verify my own transactions and balance and know it is up to date and trustworthy 3. If I send a tx to my node and others do too, then other nodes know the node ip, and somewhat hides my ip (yes you can vpn and so on as well) 4. I want to investigate some data on chain 5. It is fun and interesting to know the internals of running a node. 6. The more nodes running, the harder it is to censor the network. 7. Did I say it was fun? I learnt a lot about nginx, certs, reverse proxies, compiling with go, networking and so on (edited)
1
1
1

thedarkjester 26-Sep-21 09:01 AM
Missed this. I did a talk on Thursday which will be shared soon. However: https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon At least 2tb of disk space (ssd or faster {nvme}) - I use a Samsung T5 2tb via USB3.0 A decent CPU (a lot of time spent is single threaded execution, so more ghz is better). I did it on an overclocked Pi that took weeks to sync, so keep that in mind. It has to be a 64bit OS (I tried 32bit and got integer overflow errors and confirmed with the team it has to be 64bit)
GitHub - ledgerwatch/erigon: Ethereum implementation on the efficie...

Adewale 28-Sep-21 07:16 AM
Hello everyone, I have a question regarding how miners mine a new block. When miners are competing to create a new block, do they pickup the same number of transactions from the mempool to mine? If no, for cases with uncle blocks, will the transactions that made it to uncle block be mined in another block? Thank you
1
Adewale
Hello everyone, I have a question regarding how miners mine a new block. When miners are competing to create a new block, do they pickup the same number of transactions from the mempool to mine? If no, for cases with uncle blocks, will the transactions that made it to uncle block be mined in another block? Thank you
thedarkjester 28-Sep-21 07:50 AM
Miners pick up and prioritise the most profitable ones they can stick in a block within the short timeframe from the pool of transactions. Those processed on an uncle block are not on the longest chain, so they would end up back in the tx pool to be mined elsewhere. (edited)
1
thedarkjester
Miners pick up and prioritise the most profitable ones they can stick in a block within the short timeframe from the pool of transactions. Those processed on an uncle block are not on the longest chain, so they would end up back in the tx pool to be mined elsewhere. (edited)

Question about EIP 1559. In the Finematics video (https://youtu.be/MGemhK9t44Q?t=704), the narrator says ETH could be deflationary if "block reward + tip < base fee". Block reward is supply creation, base fee is supply destruction, but isn't the tip just a transfer from users to miners? Why is the tip part of this equation?
Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs 28-Sep-21 01:15 PM
I'm not 100% on this but I believe it's because the baseFee is the programmatic level of ETH being created, like a target. However, during crunch times where there are a lot of transactions, the baseFee will get so high as to destroy the overall amount of ETH (if only temporarily).
1
Jodo
Question about EIP 1559. In the Finematics video (https://youtu.be/MGemhK9t44Q?t=704), the narrator says ETH could be deflationary if "block reward + tip < base fee". Block reward is supply creation, base fee is supply destruction, but isn't the tip just a transfer from users to miners? Why is the tip part of this equation?
thedarkjester 28-Sep-21 01:22 PM
I think you have a point there. If you work with the amount of ETH entering (block reward) being less than the amount of ETH being burnt then it is deflationary. My understanding is like yours - the tip is non-destructive miner incentive. (edited)

Sorry I'm catching up on discord, I'm in the smart contracts chapter this week. Regarding the blocks, I'm curious to know who dictates how many transactions go into a block.
JR_Madrid
Sorry I'm catching up on discord, I'm in the smart contracts chapter this week. Regarding the blocks, I'm curious to know who dictates how many transactions go into a block.
thedarkjester 30-Sep-21 06:27 PM
transaction sizes summed need to be within block limits, cost of transactions/gas limits and time are all factors
g2dx 30-Sep-21 07:26 PM
and what prevents a transaction to be included in multiple blocks ? for example if we have 5 txs broadcasted, and miner X creates a valid block with tx 1, 2 and 5, Miner Y creates a block with tx 3, 4 and 5
g2dx
and what prevents a transaction to be included in multiple blocks ? for example if we have 5 txs broadcasted, and miner X creates a valid block with tx 1, 2 and 5, Miner Y creates a block with tx 3, 4 and 5
thedarkjester 30-Sep-21 07:36 PM
Each address has a sequential nonce, so transactions stemming from an address e.g. g2dx.eth will have a set of transaction sequences. 1,2,3,4,5 have to be executed in that order. This helps prevent duplicates, and if the longest chain already has a tx 1, it can't be executed again, it will be invalidated by the network.

thedarkjester 02-Oct-21 01:38 PM
For me the bigger picture is presenting an alternate client, particularly in the archive node space (there are currently works on erigon compression to bring the size down even smaller). The other thing for me is removing reliance on one client type. If there is a flaw in one, those nodes could go down for patching without the entire network going down.
1

Tom Hay no DM's about MetaMask 14-Oct-21 10:16 AM
the f(message) is actually a placeholder that is saying "define a function and pass into that function a message), so in this example in the observable notebook) when you click on sha256 = f(message) it expands to show sha256 = require('https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/js-sha256/0.9.0/sha256.js')
so instead you should use sha256 = require('https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/js-sha256/0.9.0/sha256.js')
Tom Hay no DM's about MetaMask
